titleStmt.title: Multi-depot vehicle routing problem for hazardous materials transportation: A fuzzy bilevel programming

analytic.title: Multi-depot vehicle routing problem for hazardous materials transportation: A fuzzy bilevel programming

biblStruct.note: Received date: 24 August 2015 Revised date: 2 February 2017 Accepted date: 4 February 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Due to enormous demand and potential threat to public, hazardous materials transportation has been tremendously investigated in recent years. However, there are few studies focusing on multi-depot vehicle routing problem for hazardous materials transportation. In this study, we develop a fuzzy bilevel programming model for minimizing the total expected transportation risk when delivering products of hazardous materials to customers from multiple depots.

The upper level formulation allocates customers to depots under the constraints of depot capacities and customer demands, while the lower level determines the optimal path for each group of depots and customers. For obtaining the optimal solution to the proposed model, four fuzzy simulation-based heuristic algorithms are designed. Illustrative examples demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model and the four heuristics.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The development of industrial and manufacturing industries increases the production and transportation of various hazardous materials, mainly includ-Preprint submitted to Journal of L A T E X Templates February 6, 2017

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T ing toxic gas, explosives and pyrotechnics, flammable liquids, radioactive and corrosive materials, among others. Since hazardous materials are not always consumed at the site of production but are needed by kinds of agencies (i.e., factories producing hazardous products, labs of universities, manufacturers of hazardous chemicals), the tremendous demands for hazardous materials are mostly satisfied by long distance transportation. However, hazardous materials transportation may cause leakage, explosion, poisoning and some other accidents.

These types of accidents are much different from accidents on general road accidents, because the accidents of hazardous materials transportation will result in huge losses to national economy, exert threats to people's life, cause irrecoverable environment damage. For example, the "719" Special Major Transport Vehicle routing problems aim to obtaining the optimal routes for vehicles under the constraints of depot capacities and customer demands. With the increasing demands on hazardous materials, numerous studies have been conducted to optimize the routes of vehicles for reducing transportation risk. There are many hazardous materials related variants such as traveling salesman problem [4], multiple traveling salesman problem [5], multi-depot multiple traveling salesman problem [31], vehicle routing problem [32], multi-depot vehicle routing problem (MDVRP), among others. MDVRP considers cases in which more than one depot is considered. Every depot is associated with a vehicle, to serve customers with known location and limited demands. Each customer can be served by multiple vehicles. The objective is to minimize the global transportation cost or time. Due to the complexity of the problem, solving the MDVRP is

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T extremely time-consuming and intractable. To address the problem efficiently, most of the researchers preferred heuristic methods to exact algorithms.

Bilevel programming is a hierarchical optimization framework where one problem is nested within another. The outer programming is commonly referred to as the upper-level optimization task, and the inner programming is commonly referred to as the lower-level optimization task. Bilevel optimization involve two kinds of variables: the upper-level variables and the lower-level variables. From a historical prospective, bilevel optimization is closely related to the economic problem in the field of game theory [46]. Bilevel programming was initially proposed by Bracken and McGill [7] in military filed, and was subsequently applied in production and marketing decision by Bracken and McGill [8]. Multilevel programming was extensively introduced later by Candler and

Norton [9] in 1977. The bilevel optimization problem has been widely applied in many domains, such as competitive strategic bidding optimization [49], customer churn analysis [14], supply chain planning [40], facility location problem [44], and decision support technology [47]. Note that MDVRP can be formulated as hierarchical optimization problem where the planner allocates customers to depots and the carriers determine the optimal path for vehicles associated with each group of depots and customers. Although many studies have formulated different types mathematical programming models for hazardous materials transportation, there is so far no literature modeling the MDVRP as bilevel programming problem, which motivates this study intending to formulate MDVRP with bilevel programming methods.

For modeling MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation, it is of great importance in real life operations and management to concentrate on the goal of minimizing transportation risk. As the primary ingredient that differentiates hazardous materials transportation from other general types of transportation, risk involves with a measure of probability and consequence of accidents. There are many undesirable consequences resulting in a hazardous materials transportation accidents, such as casualties, economic losses, environmental pollution and so on. Hazardous materials transportation accidents are recognized as low
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: probability events and lack enough historical data to estimate the consequence.

Therefore, it is better to handle the uncertainty of consequence as fuzziness based on experts' evaluations. In this study, we use fuzzy variables to estimate the total number of exposed people in the accident, and calculate the risk as the product of accident probability and the number of exposed people, which is similar with the risk definition by Kwon et al. [21]. The related theory of fuzzy variable is showed in the Appendix.
Recall that the problem to be addressed is the MDVRP for hazardous mate- we review related literatures on MDVRP and several classical risk assessment methods for hazardous materials transportation.

div.head: Multi-depot vehicle routing problem
div.p: The aforementioned MDVRP is a combinatorial optimization problem, which aims at serving a number of customers with a fleet of vehicles in a pregiven road network. Laporte et al. [22] transformed MDVRP into a constraint assignment problem and employed a branch-and-bound algorithm for solving the problem and obtaining the optimal solutions. Bettinelli et al. [6] investigated a branchand-cut-and-price algorithm for heterogeneous MDVRP with time window in which vehicles have different capacities. Gulczynski et al. [16] presented an integer programming-based heuristic for multi-depot split delivery vehicle routing problem with the goal to minimize total travel distance. Sitek et al. [41] proposed a multi-agent system and integrated it with a linear mixed-integer programming model for formulating the capacitated vehicle routing problem.

Venkatasubbaiah et al. [45] proposed a fuzzy goal programming method to formulate the multi-objective transportation problem. Rahimi-Vahed et al. [37] considered fleet-sizing for multi-depot and periodic vehicle routing problems and solved the optimal solutions using a modular heuristic algorithm. Li et al. [27] took time windows constrained MDVRP with the allowance of shared depot resources. MDVRP has been widely studied as reviewed previously. However, it is found the advantages of multi-level programming method has never been taken into consideration for formulating the MDVRP.

As for solution methods, traditional exact algorithms show limitations immediately when used to solve large scale and complex MDVRP, therefore heuristic algorithms are widely used, including neighborhood search [35], genetic algorithm [18], particle swarm optimization [36], among others. For instance, Polacek et al. [35] proposed a variable neighborhood search algorithm for solving
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: the MDVRP with time windows. Ho et al. [18] proposed a hybrid genetic algorithm which generates initial solutions by using the nearest neighbour heuristic.
Renaud et al. [38] addressed the MDVRP by constructing an initial feasible solution, followed by an improvement process using the tabu search. Moghadam

and Seyedhosseini [34] developed a particle swarm optimization approach to solve this kind of problem. Giosa et al. [15] investigated the extension of MDVRP and solved it with new assignment algorithms. Chvez et al. [11] incorporated multi-objective pareto ant colony algorithm for solving the MDVRP.

div.head: Risk measures for hazardous materials transportation
div.p: Hazardous materials transportation accidents have been characterized with low probability and high consequence. Therefore, transportation risk is always the most important objective which can not be ignored. With the aim to quantify the risk of transporting hazardous materials involved with both the probability of accident and its serious consequence, definitions of risk measures have been developed so far. For example, ReVelle et al. [39] proposed a population exposure model which defines the path risk as the total number
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T of affected population among all arcs, c 1 + c 2 + • • • + c n ,
div.p: where c i denotes the affected population that stretches along the ith arc. Erkut and Ingolfsson [13] proposed the maximum population exposure model
div.formula: c 1 ∨ c 2 ∨ • • • ∨ c n , which
div.p: assumes that the path risk should be the maximum arc risk. These two models only consider the distribution of population, while ignore the accident probability. Batta and Chiu [3] proposed to quantify the risk as the expected value of affected population,
div.formula: p 1 c 1 + p 2 c 2 + • • • + p n c n
div.p: , where p i denotes the accident probability at arc i. Since public perceptions of the potential risk are different under different circumstances, Abkowitz et al. [1] proposed a perceived risk model
div.formula: p 1 c α 1 + p 2 c α 2 + • • • + p n c α n
div.p: , where the constant α > 0 is a measure of the public perception. Sivakumar et al. [42] proposed a conditional risk Erkut and Ingolfsson [13] proposed an expected disutility model n i=1 p i (exp(βc i ) -1), where the nonnegative constant β is a measure of the catastrophe aversion. In addition, some other types of risk measures are also investigated. Kwon et al. [21] represented accident probability and its serious consequence as budgeted box-constrained sets for hazardous materials transportation, which actually reflect different risk attitude of decision makers: the larger the budget of uncertainty, the more riskaverse the decision maker is. Kang at al. [19] proposed a value-at-risk measure for hazardous material transportation, which is implemented by generating optimal route choices for a hazmat shipment based on a specified risk confidence level. Toumazis and Kwon [43] developed worst-case conditional value-at-risk as an advanced risk measure, which offers a flexible, risk-averse, and computationally tractable routing method that is appropriate for hazardous materials accident mitigation strategies.
div.formula: model (p 1 c 1 + p 2 c 2 + • • • + p n c n )/(p 1 + p 2 + • • • + p n ).
div.p: As employing different risk assessment approach yeilds different risk measure results. In this, study, based on the aforementioned current literatures, we introduce the commonly-used expected value model as risk measure in MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Mathematical models
div.p: In this section, we consider a transportation planning process of MDVRP with the consideration of interaction between a planner and multiple carriers.

The problem is formulated as a bilevel programming model, in which the planner assigns customers to depots at the upper level, and the carriers determine the optimal routing strategy of vehicles associated with each group of depot and customers at the lower level. The objective is to obtain the optimal solutions by minimizing the total transportation risk from depots to customers. Some necessary underlying assumptions are listed as follows:
• The numbers and locations of depots and customers are predetermined;
• The demands of customers and the capacities of depots are known;
• Each vehicle starts and ends at the same depot;
• Each customer can be served by multiple depots.
• The quantity of total supplies is equal to the quantity of total demands.

In order to get a better understanding of the problem, an illustrative example with 10 depots and 20 customers is given in Fig. 1, where the numbers labeled inside the depots and customers are their corresponding indices, and the numbers beside the depots and customers denote the depot capacities and customer demands. For example, the capacities for depots 1 and 3 are 30 and 50, and the demands for customers 11, 13, 14 are 10, 10, 17, respectively. The planner assigns customers 11, 13, 14 to depot 1, and the carrier gives the optimal route 11-14-13 with supplies 10, 17 and 3. Note that the demand for customer 13 is not satisfied. Therefore, it is also assigned to depot 3, which will offset the shortage. Notation systems

div.head: A C C E P T E D
div.formula: I number of depots J number of customers i depot index, i = 1, 2, • • • , I j customer index, j = 1, 2, • • • , J Q i capacity of depot i, i = 1, 2, • • • , I D j demand of customer j, j = 1, 2, • • • , J x ij supply quantity from depot i to customer j, i = 1, 2, • • • , I, j = 1, 2, • • • , J, which is the decision variable Z i mn if the arc from m to n is active with m, n ∈ A i , it takes value 1;
div.p: otherwise, it takes value 0, which is the decision variable.
k i number of customers assigned to depot i A i set of depot i and its customers, i.e.,
div.formula: A i = {i, j 1 , j 2 , • • • , j ki } R i mn travel risk from m to n with m, n ∈ A i , i = 1, 2, • • • , I, m = n Remark 3.1.
div.p: Note that k i and A i are determined by the values of decision variables x ij , according to the following expressions
div.formula: k i = {j|x ij > 0, j = 1, 2, • • • , J} , A i = {i} ∪ {j|x ij > 0, j = 1, 2, • • • , J}. A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Risk model
div.p: Risk is a measure of occurrence probability and consequence of accidents, which is the issue that distinguishes hazardous materials transportation from general transportation problems. A commonly used risk measure is defined by Batta and Chiu [3] as follows:

R i mn = P mn × κ mn × τ mn where P mn is the occurrence probability of accident, κ mn denotes affected area of the accident, and τ mn represents average population density around the accident. Hence the product κ mn × τ mn denotes the total number of affected population. As the population density around the accident is generally uncertain, it is better to estimate it as a fuzzy variable. Thus the risk measure is also a fuzzy variable.

div.head: Bilevel programming model
div.p: Based on the aforementioned descriptions of assumptions, notations, and fuzzy risk measure, we formulate the MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation as the following fuzzy bilevel programming model
div.formula:                                  min I i=1 R(x i1 , x i2 , • • • , x iJ ) s.t. J j=1 x ij = Q i , i = 1, 2, • • • , I I i=1 x ij = D j , j = 1, 2, • • • , J x ij ≥ 0, i = 1, 2, • • • , I, j = 1, 2, • • • , J, A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T where                                              R(x i1 , x i2 , • • • , x iJ ) = min E   m,n∈Ai,m =n R i mn Z i mn   s.t. m∈Ai,m =n Z i mn = 1, n ∈ A i n∈Ai,m =n Z i mn = 1, m ∈ A i m,n∈S Z i mn ≤| S | -1, S ⊂ A i , 2 ≤| S |≤ k i Z i mn ∈ {0, 1}.
div.p: In the upper level programming, the planner assigns customers to depots for minimizing the total transportation risk. R(x i1 , x i2 , • • • , x iJ ) measures the transportation risk associated with depot i and its customers, where x ij represents the supply quantity from depot i to customer j. The first constraint ensures the capacity satisfaction of the assignment strategy for depots, the second constraint guarantees the demand satisfaction of the assignment strategy for customers, and the third constraint enforces the non-negativity restrictions on the supply quantity from depot i to customer j.

In the lower level programming, carrier i determines the optimal routing solution to minimize the transportation risk associated with depot i and its customers. E[•] measures the expected transportation risk; R i mn defines the risk associated with the route from m to n; Z i mn is 0-1 decision variable (m, n ∈ A i ), which takes value 1 if the arc from m to n is selected in a feasible solution, and 0 otherwise. The constraints of the lower level programming stay the same with classical traveling salesman problem. The first two constraints ensure each customer must be visited exactly once. The third constraint is subtour elimination constraint. The fourth constraint is 0-1 decision variable.

div.head: Fuzzy simulation
div.p: The lower level programming calculates the fuzzy expected value
div.formula: E m,n∈Ai,m =n R i mn Z i mn .
div.p: Therefore, we introduce a numerical-integration-based fuzzy simulation algorithm method proposed by Li [30] to approximate the mapping
div.formula: U : x x x → E[f (x x x, ξ ξ ξ)]
div.p: where f is a real valued function.
Assume that the fuzzy vector ξ ξ ξ = (ξ 1 , ξ 2 , • • • , ξ m ) has a joint credibility function ν. Randomly generate vectors y y y 1 , y y y 2 , • • • , y y y N and calculate the credibilities
For any real number r, it follows from Theorem A1. (See Appendix) that the credibility Cr{f (x x x, ξ ξ ξ) ≥ r} can be estimated by
div.formula:        max{ν k |f (x x x, y y y k ) ≥ r}, if max{ν k |f (x x x, y y y k ) ≥ r} < 0.5 1 -max{ν k |f (x x x, y y y k ) < r}, if max{ν k |f (x x x, y y y k ) ≥ r} ≥ 0.5,
div.p: and the credibility Cr{f (x x x, ξ ξ ξ) ≤ r} can be estimated by
div.formula:        max{ν k |f (x x x, y y y k ) ≤ r}, if max{ν k |f (x x x, y y y k ) ≤ r} < 0.5 A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Algorithm 1: Bisection algorithm (Pessimistic value simulation)
Step 1: Initialize a small positive number ε.
Step 2: Randomly generate y y y i with credibilities ν i for all i = 1, 2, • • • , I.
Step 3: Calculate the minimum value a = min{f (x x x, y y y i ) | 1 ≤ i ≤ I} and the
div.formula: maximum value b = max{f (x x x, y y y i ) | 1 ≤ i ≤ I}.
div.p: Step 4: Set r = (a + b)/2.
Step 5: If Cr{f (x x x, ξ ξ ξ) ≤ r} ≥ α, set b = r. Otherwise, set a = r.
Step 6: If ba > ε, go to step 4.
Step 7: Return (a + b)/2 as the α-pessimistic value.

According to Definition 8, the α-pessimistic value is the smallest value which satisfies L(r) = Cr{f (x x x, ξ ξ ξ) ≤ r} ≥ α. Since L(r) is an increasing function, we can calculate the minimal value by using the bisection search (See Algorithm 1).

Suppose that ξ 1 , ξ 2 , • • • , ξ m are independent ordinary fuzzy variables. If f : m → is continuous and strictly increasing with respect to y y y 1 , y y y 2 , • • • , y y y m , Li [30] designed the following numerical integration algorithm (See Algorithm 2), to calculate the expected value.
Algorithm 2: Numerical-Integration-Based (NIB) algorithm (Expected value simulation)
Step 1: Initialize the number of integration points N .
Step 2: Set e = 0 and n = 1.
Step 3: By using bisection algorithm for pessimistic value simulation, calcu-
div.formula: late β i = (ξ i ) inf (n/N ) for all 1 ≤ i ≤ m.
div.p: Step 4:
div.formula: Reset e = e + f (β 1 , β 2 , • • • , β m )/N and n = n + 1.
div.p: Step 5: If n ≤ N , go to Step 3.
Step 6: Return the simulation value e.

div.head: Customers assignment
div.p: Randomly generate a customer sequence
div.formula: C 1 , C 2 , • • • , C J with demands D 1 , D 2 , • • • , D J .
div.p: Calculate the cumulative demands Cum j for the first j customers.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: We use
div.formula: Q 1 , Q 2 , • • • , Q I to
k , C k+1 , • • • , C J , denoted as Cum k , Cum k+1 , • • • , Cum J . Define U j = Cum j -Q 2 for j = k, k + 1, • • • , J.
div.p: Repeat this process until all customers are assigned to depots.
An illustrative example for assigning customers to depot 1 with Q 1 = 40 is shown in Fig. 2.
Cumulative Demand (Cumj)

Customer Demand (Dj)
The customers assigned to depot 1

div.head: Hybrid particle swarm optimization
div.p: Inspired by the predation behavior of the bird in nature, particle swarm optimization (PSO) was initially introduced by Kennedy and Eberhart [20]. Genetic algorithm (GA) in the field of artificial intelligence is a search heuristic that mimics the process of natural selection. John Holland [17] in 1970's originally proposed GA as heuristic (also sometimes called a metaheuristic) to generate useful solutions to optimization and search problems. Due to its robustness and well performance in generating optimal solutions to complex combinatorial optimization problems, PSO and GA have been widely used. In this study, a hybrid heuristic algorithm combining PSO and GA is proposed, which is associated with procedures of initialization, evaluation, selection, crossover, and mutation.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Initialization
div.p: Denote pop size particles generated by customers assignment process as

div.head: Evaluation
div.p: Generally speaking, the particle with higher fitness value should have more chance to generate offsprings. Here, the fitness is measured by objective value.

div.head: Denote the fitness of particle as
div.formula: Eval(V t ), t = 1, 2, • • • , pop size.

div.head: Selection
div.p: We employ the method of spinning roulette wheel to select particles. For any t = 1, 2, • • • , pop size, we calculate
div.formula: q t = t s=1 Eval(V s ).
div.p: Generate a random number r ∈ [0, q pop size ]. Select the zth particle if q z < r ≤ q z+1 . Repeat the above process pop size times to get pop size particles.

div.head: Crossover
div.p: Crossover operation is conducted between each individual particle and the current optimal particle. Randomly select genes segment A in an individual particle. In the current optimal particle, we find and remove the genes located in segment A, denoted by B. Generate the child as the combination of B and A. Select the particle from the parent and the child with smaller objective value to replace the parent. An illustrative example of crossover operation is shown in Fig. 3.

div.head: Mutation
div.p: Randomly generate two genes in individual particle. Change them and generate a child. Choose the particle with lower objective value from the parent and the child. The mutation process is shown by Fig. 4. Fuzzy simulation-based hybrid particle swarm optimization Fuzzy simulation hybrid particle swarm optimization (FSPSO) is the combination of fuzzy simulation and hybrid particle swarm optimization. We summarize the algorithm as follows:

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Fuzzy simulation-based genetic algorithm
div.p: Genetic algorithm was first proposed in [17] and has been widely applied in many areas. By replacing the hybrid particle-swarm optimization algorithm with genetic algorithm, we design a fuzzy simulation-based genetic algorithm (FSGA).
The main difference between FSPSO and FSGA lies in the crossover operation. The former conducts crossover operation between each individual particle

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Algorithm 3: FSPSO
Step 1: Randomly initialize pop size particles.
Step 2: Calculate the fitness values for all particles by using the fuzzy simulation algorithm.
Step 3: Generate the next generation of particles via the selection, crossover and mutation operations.
Step 4: Repeat Step 2 to Step 5 G max times.
Step 5: Return the best found particle with the smallest fitness value. and the current optimal particle, while the latter conducts the crossover operation on two randomly selected particles.

div.head: Fuzzy simulation-based ant colony algorithm
div.p: Ant colony optimization was developed in [12], and has been widely applied to solve a number of combinatorial optimization problems such as school bus routing problem, traveling salesman problem and VRP. Here, we design a fuzzy simulation-based ant colony optimization (FSACO) algorithm to solve the bilevel programming model.

div.head: Fuzzy simulation-based simulated annealing algorithm
div.p: Simulated annealing (SA) was first introduced in [33] and has been applied to various combinatorial optimization problems, which consists of solution representation, neighborhood generation, fitness evaluation, and tuning SA parameters. Here, we also design a fuzzy simulation-based simulated annealing (FSSA) algorithm to solve the bilevel programming model.

div.head: Numerical experiments
div.p: In this section, we conduct numerical experiments on the formulated fuzzy bilevel programming model of MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation, which is associated with 10 depots and 20 customers. As is shown in Fig. 5, the squares denote depots and the circles denote customers. The numbers on the

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T left side of squares and circles respectively represent the quantities of supplies and demands. The transportation risk between customers and depots are given in Tables 1 and2. Taking row 1 and column 2 for an example, it means that the risk from depot 2 to customer 1 is defined as a triangular fuzzy variable (145, 150, 160). The transportation risk among customers are given in Tables 3 and4. As the risk from customer i to customer j is the same with the risk from customer j to customer i, we only list the lower triangular part for simplicity.
We initialize both the number of integration points and the number of sample points to be 200, and preset the confidence level as 0.98. The parameters of heuristic algorithms are given in Table 5.

By running the above four algorithms with the personal computer environment: Intel i5-4460 CPU, 3.20 GHz, 4 GB RAM and Windows 10 operating system, the computational results are showed in Fig. 6 and Table 6, where Fig. 6 represents the best found path graphic and the convergence curve generated by using FSPSO and FSACO, respectively. The optimal path solution, total transportation risk, and computation time are given in Table 6. Among the aforementioned four heuristics, FSPSO and FSGA are involved with the processes of crossover and mutation, which aims to maintain the diversity of population set. The difference between FSPSO and FSGA exists mainly in the crossover operator: FSPSO conduct crossover operation between each individual particle and the current optimal particle, while FSGA randomly conduct crossover operation within the population set. As shown in Table 6, FSPSO performed much better than FSACO to find the the optimal solution but consumed longer computation time.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Table 2
div.p: The transportation risk between customers and depots The main contributions of this study are as follows: firstly, we formulated MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation; secondly, the modeling concept of bilevel programming approach was employed to handle with MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation. Thirdly, fuzzy optimization was considered to measure the risk during the transportation from depot to customers. Finally, four fuzzy simulation-based heuristic algorithms was designed for solving the optimal solutions to the proposed model. Comparative experiments were used to evaluate their performances for searching the optimal routing and allocation strategy. The different computation times were also recorded. These experimental results indicated the robustness and stability of the four heuristics. In addition, it was shown that the fuzzy simulation-based particle swarm optimization algorithm (FSPSO) performs the best on optimality but consumes longer computation time. The fuzzy simulation-based ant colony algorithm (FSACO) performs better to find the best solution within shorter computation time but fails to grantee the optimality of the found solution to the model. For further analysing the advantages of using the expected value model, we compared it with deterministic model to find the optimum solutions. The computational results show that the total transportation risk obtained by expected value model is lower than that using their deterministic models, reaching 2.2%, 4.7%, 2.0%, and 8.4%, respectively. The optimal routing solution obtained by deterministic model was took into the formulated fuzzy bilevel programming model which was solved to optimality using FSPSO. The optimal solution obtained by uti-
div.formula: D6 D7 D8 D9 D10 A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Appendix: Credibility Theory
div.p: For a good understanding on this paper, some basic concepts and theorems on credibility measure and fuzzy variables are introduced.

Let Θ be a nonempty set, and let P be the power set (i.e., the collection of all subsets). Each element of P is called an event. A credibility measure is a set function from P to [0,1], which indicates the chance of occurrence for each event. In order to ensure that the set function has meaningful mathematical properties, Li and Liu [26] suggested the following axioms:
Axiom 1. Cr{Θ} = 1 for the universal set Θ.
Axiom 2. Cr{A} ≤ Cr{B} for any events A ⊆ B.
Axiom 3. Cr{A} + Cr{A c } = 1 for any events A.
Axiom 4. Cr{∪ i A i } = sup i Cr{A i } for any collection of events {A i } with sup i Cr{A i } < 0.5.

Let Θ be a nonempty set, P the power set, and Cr a credibility measure. The triplet (Θ, P, Cr) is called a credibility space. A fuzzy variable ξ is a function from a credibility space (Θ, P, Cr) to the set of real numbers [28].

figure.figDesc: Accident of Hazardous Chemicals in Shanghai-Kunming Expressway in Shaoyang, Hunan on July 19 2014 caused 54 deaths and 5.3 million direct economy loss. The "812" Tianjin explosions with a series of explosions occurred at a container storage station at the Port of Tianjin in China on August 12 2015 caused 173 deaths, 8 missing, 797 non-fatal injuries and almost 70 billion direct economy loss according to casualty report by Wikipedia 1 .

rials transportation. In this study, we formulate the problem as a fuzzy bilevel programming model, where one subproblem is embedded within another. Four heuristic algorithms, including: fuzzy simulation-based hybrid particle swarm optimization, fuzzy simulation-based genetic algorithm, fuzzy simulation-based ant colony algorithm and fuzzy simulation-based simulated annealing algorithm are developed to solve this model. Two illustrative examples are given to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed model and algorithms. By comparing the performance of these heuristic algorithms, we found the fuzzy simulation-based hybrid particle swarm optimization performs best in optimality, while fuzzy simulation-based ant colony algorithm needs the shortest computation time. The remainder of this paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, we reviewed some important literatures on MDVRP and risk measures for hazardous materials transportation. Section 3 formulates a fuzzy bilevel programming model for minimizing the total expected transportation risk when delivering products of hazardous materials to customers from multiple depots. Section 4 designs four fuzzy simulation-based heuristic algorithms, and Section 5 presents illustrative examples to show the effectiveness of the proposed model, followed by several comparative experiments demonstrating the performance of the four heuristic algorithms. Finally Section 6 concludes the paper with a brief summary and gives some potential directions for future research. A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T 2. Literature review In this paper, we concentrate on formulating MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation with the consideration of fuzzy risk measure. In what follows,

Due to the limitations of traditional exact operation optimization methods for solving large scale and complex MDVRP, heuristic algorithms show feasibility and have been widely used. In this section, we design four fuzzy simulationbased heuristics to solve the proposed bilevel programming model of MDVRP for hazrdous materials transportation. The four fuzzy simulation-based heuristics including hybrid particle-swarm optimization, genetic algorithm, simulated annealing, and ant-colony optimization.

S C R I P T lizing fuzzy optimization method can reduce the total transportation risk by (3590 -3404)/3590 × 100% = 5.2%.In our future studies, we plan to focus on integrating location-routing problem into MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation, in which the numbers and locations for depots are not fixed. Secondly, some more realistic constraints (i.e., special-line transportation, temporary warehousing, fatigue driving, government rules of banning road accessibility, among others) may also be taken into account for reporting more feasible solutions. Due to the difficulty to accurately define the transportation risk involved with road accidents for transporting hazardous materials, integrating the real historical statistics of road accidents and big data from urban transportation systems into the formulation of MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation.

A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Case studies
div.p: In this section, we implement real-life experiments to evaluate the performances of four heuristic algorithms for solving the proposed fuzzy bilevel programming model of MDVRP for hazardous materials transportation, in which the experiment data is from a petroleum chemical company in Beijing, China.

The copany has 8 oil depots and 32 gas stations, which locate in the map of Beijing as shown in Fig. 7. The concrete supply and demand are given in Fig. 8, in which the pentagrams denote oil depots and the circles denote gas stations. The numbers on the left side of pentagrams and circles represent the corresponding quantities of supplies and demands, respectively. We initialize both the number of integration points and the number of sample points to be 200, and preset the confidence level as 0.98 in the formulated programming model. The parameters of the four heuristic solution methods are given in Table 5.

For testing the stability and reliability of these four heuristic search algorithms, we perform each algorithm 10 times, and record the obtained objective values, runtime, average runtime as well as the average objective values in Table 7. It is shown that FSPSO can get the lowest objective value. The optimal solution to the formulated model using FSACO is not the best one, however it consumed shortest average runtime. Therefore, among the four heuristics, it is suggested that the FSPSO performed much better than the others. Then we adopt FSPSO as the acceptable solution approach to solve the formulated programming when the optimality is dominant. In addition, according to the aforementioned performance records, FSACO algorithm is recommended to be the proper solution method when the computation efficiency must be satisfied. The optimal routing solutions to the model and corresponding convergence curves of FSPSO and FSACO are depicted in Fig. 9. The best routing solution with the minimum total risk is shown in Table 8.

We further replace all fuzzy parameters with their expected value for evaluating the performance of the four algorithms. And then, we obtain a deterministic model. The optimal routing solution is showed in Table 9. Taking these
